rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 13   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 14   Value: 11
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 23   Value: 18
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 8    Value: 20
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 5    Value: 40
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.

	+ [Wood]    Qty: 22   Value: 12
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 22   Value: 14
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 16   Value: 29
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 21   Value: 40
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.

The game lasts for 10 turns in total.

rounds.response:
Alright, I analyze my starting position:

Current portfolio value  
(Wheat: 14×5 = 70) + (Wood: 22×12 = 264) + (Sheep: 22×14 = 308) + (Brick: 16×29 = 464) + (Ore: 21×40 = 840)  
Total = 1 946 value.

Brick and Ore dominate the value sheet: Brick = 29 / unit, Ore = 40 / unit.  
Wheat and Wood are the cheapest at 5 and 12 respectively.  
Sheep sits in the middle (14) and I have a surplus (22 units).

Goal: acquire more expensive resources (Ore & Brick) by exchanging the relatively cheaper ones (Sheep, maybe Wood) if the exchange rate is attractive.

I have no incoming offer on turn 1. I’ll propose an opener to test the market early and position myself for Ore growth:

[Offer: 6 Sheep, 4 Wood -> 5 Ore, 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
I just lost some value here: giving away 6 Sheep × 14 = 84 and 4 Wood × 12 = 48 (total 132) for 5 Ore × 40 = 200 and 1 Brick × 29 = 29 (total 229) is a +97 value swing for me but was still rejected. That tells me Player 0 probably wants more generous trades or different resources.

Given the refusal, I should:

1. Avoid over-paying (my last offer already was favorable to them beyond its intrinsic value).
2. Figure out what resource they are short of.  
   My Brick (29) and Ore (40) are my highest value items, so P0 is telling me they value theirs even more.

Best readjustment: I still have plenty of Sheep (16 left) and Wood (18 left). I’ll let Player 0 acquire the cheaper-ranks of value they might be low on while I continue hoarding Ore/Brick.

Next proposal—offer them cheaper items for equal ore/brick.

[Offer: 6 Wood, 5 Sheep -> 4 Ore, 2 Brick]

[Deny]

I need more Ore and Brick is quite valuable to me. The offer doesn't provide enough value in return for the resources requested. I'll wait for a better deal.

rounds.response:
Turn-by-turn valuation, opponent signal & plan

Current portfolio and unit prices
Item        Qty   Value  Value/q
Ore         21    40     1.90
Brick       16    29     1.81
Sheep       22    14     0.64
Wood        22    12     0.55
Wheat       14     5     0.36

Key facts
- Sheep & Wood have the lowest single-unit value.
- Ore has the highest per-unit value.
- So far Player 0 has passed every opportunity; this suggests they
  (a) do not want to give up Ore, or
  (b) the quantities offered were too small / unbalanced.

New single round Bayesian guess
– Player 0 is Ore-starved (needs more).  
– They probably possess a surplus of Sheep, Wood, Wheat; maybe Brick.

Lever we will test in the next offer

Target 1: Ship some of our 22 extra Wood and 22 extra Sheep (≥2 units) for highest-value assets (Ore).  
Target 2: Keep our Brick/Ore gap (exchange span) still improving total score.  
Lean 3: Ask only for Ore (most inelastic good) and give 1.4-to-1 value on our worst two goods.

Computation for the trade we are about to make:
give = 4 Sheep (0.64 each) + 2 Wood (0.55 each) = 3.58 value  
take = 3 Ore (1.90 each)                       = 5.70 value  
Net ≈ +2.12 value, fully aligned with their (probable) needs.

Action

[Offer: 4 Sheep, 2 Wood -> 3 Ore]

rounds.response:
Let me calculate the exact value change my rejected offers would have yielded:

Offer 1 (6 Sheep + 4 Wood → 5 Ore + 1 Brick):  
Loss = 6×14 + 4×12 = 132  
Gain = 5×40 + 1×29 = 229  
Net value increase = +97 → rejected

Offer 2 (6 Wood + 5 Sheep → 4 Ore + 2 Brick):  
Loss = 6×12 + 5×14 = 142  
Gain = 4×40 + 2×29 = 218  
Net value increase = +76 → rejected

Offer 3 (4 Sheep + 2 Wood → 3 Ore):  
Loss = 4×14 + 2×12 = 80  
Gain = 3×40 = 120  
Net value increase = +40 → rejected

I need to sweeten the deal so Player 0 accepts. The most recent offer already gives them 40 value “profit” while costing me nothing. To raise my own net gain beyond that 40, I’ll offer an even better rate—more resources from my side, more of their high-value Brick.

[Offer: 5 Sheep, 5 Wood, 2 Brick -> 5 Ore, 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
Current totals
- Wheat: 14×5 = 70  
- Wood: 22×12 = 264  
- Sheep: 22×14 = 308  
- Brick: 16×29 = 464  
- Ore: 21×40 = 840  
Current value = 1 946

I’ve so far leaned on sheep + wood to buy ore, but we’ve had zero traction.  
Player 0 clearly wants something different, and my ore offer was already generous.

Take a fresh angle: tempt them with 1-for-1 or near-parity brick gains, since brick is only 29 value each (vs ore at 40) and I have “spare” bricks—especially if I can flip them for higher-value ore.

New pitch: slightly overpay in brick terms, but net out high in value gained.

[Offer: 4 Brick -> 3 Ore]
